title: How many VHS tapes can you fit on a DVD? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends on what speed the VHS tapes were recorded at, and how much quality you want/need from the DVD recording.  Tapes were usually recorded in SP, which gave 2 hours per tape. (There were also 4 and 6 hour settings at lower recording quality if you really wanted to jam a lot of material on a tape.) With a DVD, an acceptable bitrate for recording something as low res as VHS would be 4 megabits per second. (DVD supports as high as 10 megabits per second but that's overkill for VHS) On a single layer recordable disc, that bitrate gives you about 2 hours.  So, the answer is: one tape. Two if it's a dual layer disc.  Of course you can lower the bitrate and get more tapes on, but image quality will suffer.

Less than one VHS tape recorded at EP speed. Maybe one if you are willing to compromise quality on the DVD recording. One for SP speed and a good recording. If you were to use a good codec like H.264, you could put files for a lot more than 6 hours on a DVD, but few DVD players could play it. A computer could.
